AC4101

A

4th

Frederick Douglass

Activists

1818-1895

Taking the surname "Douglass" after gaining his freedom, he became a spokesman for abolitionist societies and the US Constitution's 3/5 clause. For 17 years, he published and managed a newspaper supporting black freedom. During the Civil War, he used his fame to recruit free African Americans into the Union Army, contributing to its  victory.  

Douglass inspires all your black Characters. For every black Character in your Civilization, increase his Land's Defense by 200.

AC4102

A

4th

Susan B. Anthony

Activists

1820-1906

Anthony, along with Fredrick Douglass and Elizabeth Cady Stanton, was an icon of the suffrage movement. For 15years, her teaching career had limited her time for activism, so she quit her job to fight for civil rights and to co-found  a women’s rights journal. Anthony and Stanton helped write the 19th constitutional amendment.

Anthony adds strength to female Characters. For every woman in your Civilization, increase your Morale by 200.

Army

1066 - 1604

The dawn of the English Army began when William the Conqueror defeated the Celts on the Isle of Britton in 1066.  The English Army and its  legendary longbows were feared in Europe through the end of the Hundred Years’ War.  Later, it  became known as the British Army when King James I formed Great Britain in 1604.

The English Army increases his Land’s Strength by 300 if it fights  on behalf of the United Kingdom or an English Leader.

A

4th

Mongolian Army (Cover)

Army

1206BC - 1368AD

Genghis Khan unified all Mongolian territories into the Mongol Empire in 1206 AD and combined the territorial warriors into one army. This army conquered all of Asia, the Middle East, and parts of Eastern Europe. Considered the first modern military system, it  used foreign weapons and, to a small extent, warships.

The Mongolian Army wins its  first attack on any Land, beating any other card with the same type of ability.

June 30, 1892

In 1892, Pennsylvania steel workers became enraged when Andrew Carnegie failed to give them a promised wage increase. In a standoff known as the Homestead Strike, the workers  revolted and blocked efforts to bring in scab workers to resume production. The US military stepped in when the uprising turned violent and a battle ensued.

As a well-educated former slave, , Bowser worked as a spy in the Jefferson Davis household during the Civil War. A

4th

Jesse Owens

Athlete

1895-1948

Jesse Owens, the grandson of a slave, achieved something no Olympian before him had ever accomplished. At the 1936 Berlin Olympic Games, he earned four gold medals. His outstanding performance discredited Adolph Hitler's heinous claims about racial superiority. His long-jump world record stood for 25 years.

Jesse Owens' inspires your people. Increase your Morale by 200.

1898 - 1963

Irish-born Lewis dreamed up many vivid imaginary worlds as a child. Early into his university studies, Lewis left Christianity for atheism. WWI service and further studies saw him return to his Christian faith and to a quest for truth. His faith can be found in many of his writings including his Narnia series.

Famous for The Odyssey and The Iliad, Homer's personal history is largely unknown. Some scholars say he was Greek, others Babylonian. Some say his epics were autobiographical; others mention his travels as a wandering minstrel. Regardless, Homer's influence on early European literature is unquestionable.

1867-1919

Born Sarah Breedlove, she created a specialized line of hair-care products for African American hair. She was the first female African American self-made millionaire. While seeking a treatment for her own hair loss, she developed the “Walker system.” From then on she was known as Madam CJ Walker.

Charlemagne, the 8th century King of the Franks, was honored by Rome after assuming the Iron Crown of Italy. While Charlemagne was battling Spain, the Romans threatened Pope Leo III. Charlemagne returned to defend Leo and was crowned the first Holy Roman Emperor. The Catholic Church still hails him as the first Champion of Christianity.

Eric Bloodaxe

Conqueror

885 - 954

Eric Bloodaxe was a greatly feared 10th century king of Western Norway. Ousted from the throne by his more popular half-brother, he moved to the British Isles, raided Scotland and Ireland, and established himself as ruler of the Viking Kingdom of Northumbria until his death in 954 AD. His sons later took back Norway.  His name continued to spread fear posthumously.

Colonial Representatives from the 13 colonies met in the Pennsylvania State House in May 1787 to revise the Articles of Confederation. Adam Smith

Economists

1723-1790

Scottish-born Smith studied to be a political economist and became a professor of logic and of moral philosophy at Glasgow University. His two iconic books were The Theory of Moral Sentiments, written in 1759, and The Wealth of Nations, written in 1776. .  Smith laid the intellectual framework for the free market we enjoy today.

Dark Ages

Events

5th to 10th Centuries

The Dark Ages is mostly recognized as the time between the end of the Western Roman Empire and the beginning of the Italian Renaissance. This period gets its name from the western European decline in historical record-keeping, the waning of Latin literacy and cultural achievements, and the demographic deterioration in Europe experienced during this time.

625-Unknown BC

Thales of Miletus was a philosopher and mathematician, and is renowned as one of the Seven Wise Men of antiquity.  He is primarily remembered for his cosmology, for his study of natural sciences, and for his theories of water as being the essence of all matter, with Earth being a flat disk floating on a vast sea.  He is said to be the first to ask, “What is the basic 'stuff' of the universe?”

Newton's Law of Motion

Knowledge

1643–1727

These laws describe the relationship between forces acting on a mass and its motion:  1. If a body is at rest it remains at rest or if it is in motion it moves with uniform velocity unless acted on by an outside force. 2. Force is equal to mass times acceleration. 3.  For every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction.

With this Knowledge, pull any one Technology Card from your deck and play it immediately. Reshuffle your deck.

Gladiatrices, or female gladiators, were  common in ancient Rome until 200 AD. Like the male gladiators, they fought people and animals for the entertainment of Roman spectators. Philolaus  and other Pythagorean philosophers (5th c. BC ), were the first to hypothesize a non-geocentric universe.  However, Aristarchus of Samos (3rd c. Events

79 AD

On 24 Aug 79 AD, the citizens of Pompeii faced one of Europe's most catastrophic events.  The city was in the shadow of Mount Vesuvius, which suffered a pyroclastic eruption.  This resulted in over 13,000 deaths.  The 1595 discovery of the Pompeii ruins revealed many bodies covered in ash and frozen in time.

Galveston Hurricane of 1900

Events

1900

The Great Galveston Hurricane of 1900 was a Category 4 storm that made landfall on 8 Sept 1900, near Galveston, Texas.  It had winds estimated at 145 mph at landfall and is the most deadly hurricane in US history, having taken 6,000-12,000 lives.  It was so powerful that it still had 45 mph winds when it reached Milwaukee, Wisconsin.

Conqueror

A loyal supporter and great friend of Julius Caesar, Lepidus served as Caesar’s “Master of the Horse,” or deputy. After Caesar’s assassination, Lepidus joined Mark Antony in declaring Augustus (Caesar Octavianus) the adopted son of Julius Caesar. Hispania and Africa but was later exiled and stripped of his powers by Augustus.

4th

Cimbrian War

Event

113–101 BC

In 113 BC, Cimbrian troops attacked Roman territories and armies west of Rome, prompting defeated Romans to hold a special meeting that elected Gaius Marius, victor of the Jugurtha War, as consul. In 102 BC, Marius established a well-fortified camp and lured Cimbri troops to attack. He then surprised the Cimbrians by striking them from the rear and

capturing their king. Cimbri retaliated by pillaging much of northern Italy, but Marius took advantage of their location and annihilated them.

Gladiator Wars

Event

73–71 BC

In 73 BC, a band of 78 gladiator-slaves escaped imprisonment and began recruiting an army of 120,000 men, women, and children who formed small bands intent on taking over Rome itself.  One band, led by the gladiator-general Spartacus, became famous for its great military strategies and had two years of victory overcoming Roman attacks. Spartacus’s army was eventually defeated in southern Italy. Six thousand of his surviving troops were crucified, their crosses lining the road from Rome to Capua.

EVRR406

1

4th

Latin Wars

Event

340–338 BC

In 503 BC, despite a treaty formed between Rome and the Latin League, the two Roman colonies of Pometia and Cora defected from Rome, followed by several more defections. By 383 BC, revolts were becoming more common and Rome declared war.  In 361 BC, the Tiburtes and Gauls joined forces and attacked Rome at night. In the end, the Latin people surrendered, withdrew from many cities close to Rome, and made an appeasement with Rome. They broke this treaty in 340 BC, lost another war to Rome, and many more cities were annexed, creating a model of how Rome would treat colonies and defeated states in the future.

Any of your Lands taken within the last two turns are now returned. Your opponent’s Characters in that Land are exiled to the discard pile.

Fabius Maximus

Leader

280–203 BC

Fabius was a great political leader and military general who was credited as the father of guerrilla warfare because of his strategic targeting of enemy supply lines despite being outnumbered. He served as Roman consul and influenced the start of the First Punic War. Greatly revered by the people, Fabius bravely protected his troops from destruction, sacrificed his office of dictator for the good of the people, and gave credit for his victories to the gods.

4th

The Executive Magistrate

Organization

510-44 BC

Roman citizens had the right to elect their magistrates, who were separated into ranks and given differing powers according to their roles, including: censors, consuls or chief magistrates, praetors, curule aediles, and quaestors. Higher magistrates could veto any bill a lower magistrate issued. In times of emergency, a dictator magistrate would be called and given all power, unchecked by any institution.

Choose a Character as magistrate.  All Characters in that Land are given the same Strength as the magistrate for one turn only.

4th

The Legislative Assembly

Organization

509–27 BC

Under the Roman Constitution, the people, known as the Assembly, had the final say on issues including: the enactment of new statutes, the carrying out of capital punishment, the declaration of war and peace, and the creation or dissolution of alliances. As a direct democracy, the people were given the power to vote  on issues of procedure and legality. In the first decade of the Republic, the people of Rome voted on legislation, elected consuls, and tried judicial cases.

Your Morale will not decrease for the next two turns. Increase your Morale an additional 200 for each of those two turns.

ORRR403

4th

The Senate

Organization

753 BC-476 AD

Roman senators were usually appointed by those in power rather than through a democratic vote by the people. Originally, the magistrates would select and release those in the Senate, or when a magistrate fulfilled his term, he would then be moved to the Senate. This powerful organization controlled the day-to-day life of Roman citizens as well as matters of finance, administration, and foreign affairs of state.  

You gain control of any opponent's Organization in play. Move it to your Civilization or discard it.

Cilician Pirates

Outlaws

2nd c. - 66 BC

After the Hannibalic Wars, all naval forces were destroyed except for the ships of Cilician pirates. Because the pirates were the most feared naval force at the time, most ports were forced to become a safe haven to them. Their main cargo was human cargo—slaves who were sold to Roman plantations. This trade was so profitable that up to 100,000 slaves were traded each day until 67 BC, when Pompey the Great commissioned hundreds of ships to rid the seas of pirates.

Double the pirates’ Attack unless you face another Roman Leader or Conqueror.

Politician

106-48 BC

Ally to both Roman dictator Sulla and opposition leader consul Cinna, Magnus, known in English as Pompey the Great, raised a private army that sided with Sulla to destroy his enemies in Sicily and Africa, which earned him the title “teenage butcher.” Much of his life was politically influenced, including his marriage with Julius Caesar’s own daughter, Julia. Later in his life, his betrayal of Caesar forced him to flee Rome.

Roman Ballista

Technology

400 BC

Developed from earlier Greek weapons, the ballista launched large projectiles at targets over long distances. Its tension mechanics varied depending on the objective and the type of projectile, which could include rocks, arrows, or other items. This large weapon was later redesigned as a smaller, more mobile unit which was the forefather of the crossbow. The ballista and the catapult-like scorpio were highly accurate and were recorded to have taken out individual soldiers, even at great distance.

Warrior

107 BC

Centurions were Roman army and navy officers who were selected to command

legionary soldiers in their century or tribe. In battle, they were recognized by their distinctive helmets and swords as they fought alongside their men in the front. These men were some of the bravest and most loyal soldiers in all the army because they earned their rank through skill and valor in battle.

 

For showing valor—ONCE: Increase your Morale by 200. CONSTANT: Increase Strength by 500 when fighting a Land with an Army.

WAE003

1

4th

Sparticus

Warrior

111-71 BC

As an escaped gladiatorial slave who became a rebel army general, Spartacus was feared by the Roman leaders as his band of former slaves attacked Italian cities throughout the countryside. Rome sent a militia to stop Spartacus but was surprised by an attack that killed nearly all of the Roman militia. Spartacus’s ranks swelled to 70,000, and Rome sent General Crassus to defeat them.  Most of the rebels were killed on the battlefield and 6,000 of the survivors were captured and crucified, their crosses lining the road leading to Rome.

Spartacus inspires your people. For each Character with less than 100 Attack points, multiply their Strength by 10 for two rounds.

4th

Patriot Militia

Army

1774-1776

These brave men were neither educated nor trained  in military strategy. They were farmers, blacksmiths, and humble traders who shared a profound love for their new land . When the Continental Army formed, they eagerly joined the ranks, although many were never paid for their services. Some even fought barefoot after their shoes wore thin and useless. Thousands whose names were never recorded in history laid down their lives for freedom.

When any European Character is used in an attack against the Militia’s Land, increase that Land’s  Defense by 500.

4th

British Regulars

Army

18th and 19th Century

Trained from an early age in the way of military strategy, the British Regulars were the pillar of the British army. Most of the enlisted were Scottish, Irish, and Prussian. Their red coats were easily distinguishable through the black powder smoke. During the Revolutionary War, they were used to protect British property.

When commanded by a British Leader, increase their Strength by 500.

ARRW403

2

4th

Minute Men

Army

1774-1775

The Minutemen were groups of militia members made up of farmers, motivated self-trained riflemen, and veterans of the French and Indian War. Many of them were young men who were specially trained to fight for their new land at a moment’s notice. Some were used as spies within the British ranks, and

others, like Paul Revere, were dispatched to alarm the colonists of approaching danger.

 

INTERRUPT: If played in a North American Land, increase your Defense by 500 and Attack by 300.

DORW401

2

4th

Join or Die

Document

1754

Benjamin Franklin’s famous political cartoon “Join, or Die,” was first published as part of an editorial in the Pennsylvania Gazette in 1754, in an effort to unite the colonies in the French and Indian War. The drawing shows a snake cut into eight sections representing some the original colonies or regions. It became a world-renowned symbol of freedom when it was re-used during the Revolutionary War.

INTERRUPT: Choose a Character card from your discard pile to rejoin the fight for a Land that is under attack.

4th

Battle on Concord

Event

April 19, 1775

Unable to hold off the Redcoats in Lexington, the colonists retreated to Concord. The British followed, destroying the town’s cannons and setting fire to the colonial meetinghouse.  Seeing smoke, colonists spread the news that the British were burning Concord, and hundreds of militia and Minutemen hurriedly gathered around the city and forced the British to retreat.

EVRW402

2

4th

Battle on Lexington Green

Event

April 19, 1775

In Lexington, 80 militiamen gathered outside Buckman Tavern early one morning and awaited orders. They were told to line one side of the commons, but not to fire until fired upon. The advanced team of British light infantry marched out of the trees and took up position. They too were warned not to fire. With the fateful “shot heard round  the world,” the Revolutionary War began, though the hand that first discharged his weapon was never discovered.

Event

America’s fight for independence began when

ordinary people courageously stood against oppressive British rule at the Battles of Lexington and Concord on April 19, 1775. As Captain John Parker proclaimed on that extraordinary morning, “If they mean to have a war, let it begin here.”

Captain Parker

Leader

1729-1775

This man literally dropped his plow to fulfill his duty to the colonies as commander of the Lexington militia. His men vowed to protect colonists’ weapons and provisions as they faced 700 well-trained British troops. Setting up barricades before dawn, Parker stood unflinchingly with his men as the Regulars approached. To his men, Parker bravely declared, “Don't fire unless fired upon, but if they mean to have a war, let it begin here."

If a Land Parker’s occupies loses the first attack, he automatically wins the second attack.

2

4th

Dr. Joseph Warren

Leader

1741-1775

A doctor who was respected by both the British and the colonists, Dr. Warren received a message from an informant that the British Regulars were marching to Concord to take the colonial militia’s weapons and arrest John Hancock and Samuel Adams. He enlisted Paul Revere and William Dawes to warn the colonists . Later, he played a key role in the Massachusetts Congress. He was commissioned as a major general  before the battle on Breed’s Hill , and instead of pulling rank he humbly fought among his men as a private and was killed in battle.

Warren will turn any of your opponent’s Spies or Assassins into double agents and you may use their Abilities against their owner.

Lieutenant Colonel Francis Smith

Leader

1723-1791

Smith’s orders were to search out and confiscate the colonial militia’s artillery and provisions in Lexington and Concord. He selected 700 elite Regular soldiers to stealthily complete the mission. Some of his men marched ahead to Lexington and then to Concord where many were killed or wounded when the colonists fought back. As he and his men retreated, they were ambushed by the Lexington militia and Smith was wounded.

Brigadier General Hugh Percy.

Leader

1742-1817

Percy, Duke of Northumberland, served as an officer in the British army during the Revolutionary War. Initially sympathetic to the colonists, he later despised them for being uncivilized. His military strategies saved the retreating British after the disastrous Battle of Concord. Percy later resigned his position and returned to England after a disagreement with his commanding officer, General Howe.

4th

James Barrett

Leader

1710-1779

Col. Barrett was the first recorded colonist to fire a shot at the British  as he commanded his Minutemen at Concord’s North Bridge. After seeing the numbers of British troops flowing into Concord, he moved his militia to the hill overlooking the bridge to defend the town. Col. Barrett gave the command to fire as he pulled his own trigger. Nearly half of the British officers were among those killed in the firefight, and the rest of the Redcoats retreated in fear.

If the Land he is occupying is attacked, Barrett wins the first battle.

King George

Leader

1895-1952

Called “Pharaoh George” by American colonists (who compared themselves to the Biblical Israelites leaving Egypt), King George III  was despised by the British Parliament, which accused him of trying to take back power from it. George was tasked with stopping the colonists from rebelling against the heavy taxes laid upon them by Parliament. George failed, lost the American colonies, and eventually went mad.

2

4th

Major John Pitcairn

Leader

1722-1775

This Scottish Marine officer was well-liked by the colonists, but (ironically) the first shot of the war may have been fired contrary to his command by one of his own soldiers at Lexington on April 19, 1775. Later in the war, when he tried to take Bunker Hill, he was shot by a black slave named Peter Salem. As he fell, his own son caught him, yelling, “I have lost my father!” This signaled retreat for his troops, who mourned his impending death as they carried his body off the battlefield.

LORW401

2

4th

Old North Church - Two lantern

Location

1723-1775

“One if by land, and two if by sea ” – Two lanterns set in the Old North Church were used to warn Paul Revere and the Minutemen when the British were leaving Boston on their way to attack Lexington. Seeing two lights in the tower, Revere and William Dawes rode through the countryside hollering, “The Regulars are coming out!” (not “The British are coming,” as most colonists still considered themselves British). This historic ride would symbolize the birth of a nation and serve as a warning to all the colonies.

INTERRUPT – Warn your Civilization of an impending attack. Increase your Defense by 2000 for one turn.

LORW402

2

4th

Port of Boston

Location

1630-2020

Boston Harbor was one of the largest colonial seaports under British control. The British Parliament attempted to tax the colonists with a tea tax to pay for the French and Indian War, but a group of Bostonians, known as the Sons of Liberty, revolted by dumping the British East India Company’s tea into the harbor. Though the British were confident that this port was securely under their control, the Continental Army, under the command of General Washington, later took back this vital port and ran the British out of Massachusetts.

Increase your Morale by 300 if you have a Businessman in your Civilization.

Battle of Boston

      

LORW403

2

4th

North Bridge of Concord

Location

April 19, 1775

In Concord, Col. James Barrett surrendered the town for a stronger position across the North Bridge, outside of town. The British who arrived to guard the bridge as their route of retreat were surprised by the 200 Minutemen and other militia who were prepared to fight for their land. In a volley of bullets, almost half of the British officers fell, the surviving troops were forced to flee, and some of them mistakenly attempted to destroy their own escape route. This was the defining moment, the true “shot heard ‘round the world," when the colonists knew they could take back the colonies.  

The battle turns in your favor—ONCE: Increase your Morale by 200. CONSTANT: Increase one Land's Attack by 400.

2

4th

Margaret Kemble Gage

Spy

1734–1824

Mrs. Gage, wife of British Royal Governor Thomas Gage of Massachusetts Bay, was born in New Jersey and was sympathetic to the colonists’ fight for independence. Sources speculate that hours before Paul Revere rode to warn Lexington and Concord, Mrs. Gage secretly provided vital information to Joseph Warren about her husband’s military plans. Although he never found proof, her husband suspected her of spying and sent her back to England shortly thereafter.

 

Turn one of your opponent’s Characters into a spy and steal 1000 of your opponent’s Attack points and add that to your Defense.

Robert Newman and Captain John Pulling

Warriors

1754-1804

On the night of Paul Revere’s fateful ride, Robert Newman and Captain Pulling risked their lives to light the lanterns that would warn Revere and other Minutemen about the British army’s intentions of leaving Boston and whether they were going by land or sea. These two brave men ascended the stairs to the steeple of the tallest building in Boston, knowing they would hang for treason if caught by any of the British troops in the vicinity.

442nd Regimental Combat Team

Army

1944 - 1969

This American WW2 regiment was unique in consisting almost entirely of Japanese-American Soldiers as a self-sufficient force fighting in Europe. Its soldiers earned eight Presidential Unit Citations, 10,000 Purple Hearts, and 21 Medals of Honor, all while their families were in US internment camps.

MAW2401

3

4th

Poland's Enigma codebreakers

Mathmaticians

1939 - 1945

Early on, the Polish Cipher Bureau foresaw the potential military use of the Enigma machine. Three great mathematicians, Rejewski, Zygalski, and Różycki, joined the Bureau together and built a “bombas” machine used for decoding. When Germany threatened Poland, these men shared their knowledge with British cryptographers who went on to crack the Nazi’s more complicated Enigma code and shorten the war. The three men escaped through Romania.

South Abandons Congress

Event

Contentions ran high in Congress, leading to secession.  Animosity over slavery drove a Democratic congressman to beat his anti-slavery Republican colleague almost to death with his cane in the House Chambers.  On March 11, 1861, the Confederate Constitution was unanimously adopted.

Pony Express

Organization

1859

Stagecoach routes, which were established from Missouri to California after gold was discovered, took 25 days to deliver messages. With the possibility of a civil war, the US government desired a quicker way to transport messages from Missouri to California.  The Pony Express, assembled in 1860, took 10 days by a relay of experienced horsemen. It was disbanded with the completion of the telegraph in 1861.

Invention of the Mariner's Astrolabe

Technology

 

The mariner's astrolabe, also called sea astrolabe, was used to determine a ship's location by the noon day sun or the altitude of a known star.  They were designed to allow for their use on boats in rough waters, which astrolabes are ill equipped to handle.  It was a major advancement for the Age of Exploration.

The mariner's astrolabe enables you to double the effect of any of your sea explorers.
